title: Śāriputrābhidharmaśāstra
description: The Gandhāra region was influential in the development of the Abhidarma. Abhidarma manuscript fragments have been found there. Parellels noted with Śāriputrābhidharmaśāstra (T 1458).

title: Āgama
sources: Senior Collection, Schøyen Collection, Hirayama Collection and Bukkyo University Collection (Matsuda, 2014)
description: The texts of the Āgama are the discourses of the Buddha and direct disciples, parallel to the suttas of the Pali Canon. They were handed down by oral recitation for at least four centuries before being written down. Gāndhārī fragments from Āgama texts have been discovered in Gandhara.

title: Agrapradīpadhāraṇī
description: Khotanese fragments in the British Library collection

title: Ajatasatrukaukrtyavinodana Sūtra
description: Early Sansksrit manuscript with parallels to T 626 and other Chinese translations

title: Akṣobhya text
description: The text describes the Buddha Akṣobhya and his realm Abhirati. Gāndhārī scrolls have been discovered from the Bajaur region of Pakistan.

title: Arthapada
description: Parallel to the Pali Aṭṭhaka-vagga contained in the Sutta Nipata

title: Aśoka Major Rock Edicts
description: Kharoṣṭhī inscriptions at Shahbazgarhi and Mansehra

title: Aṣṭasāhasrikā Prajñāpāramitā
sources: Schøyen Collection; Split Collection; Hayashidera Collection (Matsuda, 2014)
description: Gāndhārī fragments of the oldest Mahāyāna text, radio carbon dated to the first century CE.

title: Arthavargīyasūtra
sources: Stein Collection in the British Museum
description: Sanskrit fagments from five consecutive folios discovered by Aurel Stein in Khadalik (near Khotan). These are parallel to the Atthaka Vagga in the Sutta Nipāta of the Pali Canon.

title: Avadāna
description: Manuscript fragments from Avadāna texts

title: Avadāna Anthology
description: Discovered in Merv, Turkmenistan

title: Bajaur Kharoṣṭhī Fragments
description: The Bajaur collection is a set of Mahāyāna birch bark Gāndhārī manuscript fragments discovered in the Bajaur district of Northwest Pakistan in 1999.

title: Bodhisattvabhūmi
description: Later Nepalese manuscript dating to about 1794 CE

title: Bodhisattvapiṭaka Sūtra
sources: Schøyen Collection, (Baums et al, 2016),  Hirayama Collection (Matsuda, 2014)
description: Schøyen Kharoṣṭhī fragment 17 corresponds to sutra no. 12 of the Ratnakūṭa group.

title: Bodhisattvapratimokṣa Sūtra
description: Later Nepalese manuscript

title: Buddhacarita
description: Stories of the life of the Buddha composed by Aśvaghoṣa with fragments from two different manuscripts, one in Brāhmī and the other in Gupta script,  not older than the 6th century

title: Dakṣiṇāvibhaṅga-sūtra
description: A text in the Madhyama-āgama.

title: Daśabhūmika Sūtra
description: A 17th century-20th century Sanskrit manuscript from Nepal written in Pracalit Newārī

title: Dharmaguputaka Vinaya
description: Discovered in German expeditions to Xinjiang in the early 20th century, including Bhikṣuprātimōkṣasūtra der Dharmaguptaka.

title: Dharmapada
description: The Dharmapada is a collection of words of wisdom in verse and one of the historically most popular Buddhist texts. A Gandhari manuscript was discovered in Khotan in 1892.

title: Diamond Sūtra
description: Parital Gāndhārī manuscripts of the Diamond Sūtra

title: Dīrghāgama
description: Partial scrolls, leaves, and fragments discovered in Northern Pakistan in the 1990s.

title: Divyāvadāna
description: A collection of Avadana stories

title: Ekottarika-āgama
description: Kharosthi manuscript fragments birch bark scrolls dating to the first-century A.D.

title: Hārītī Inscription
description: Copper-plate; Sanskrit inscription and drawing of Hārītī discovered in Indonesia

title: Huviṣka inscription
description: Demonstrating imperial sponsorship of Mahayana in the Kushan empire

title: Hastikakṣyā
description: Khotanese fragments

title: Karmavācanā
description: A Vinaya text

title: Kāśyapaparivarta
sources: St Petersburg, Hoernle, Mannerheim, and Turfan collections
description: Sanskrit fragments

title: Kusan Empire Inscriptions
sources: Skinner, Marks of Empire; Lüders, Mathura Inscriptions
description: The kings of the Kushan Empire left many inscriptions. During the reign of Kanishka I the empire extended over northern India as far as the Bay of Bengal.

title: Lalitavistara
description: Later Nepalese manuscript

title: Laṅkāvatāra
description: Later Nepalese manuscript

title: Larger Prajñāpāramitā
description: Fragments found at Dunhuang

title: Lotus Sūtra
description: Sanskrit versions of the Lotus Sutra or Saddharmapuṇḍarīka discovered at Gilgit

title: Madhyama-āgama
description: The Senior collection includes four Gāndhārī  sutras with Chinese parallels, including 1. No 213 in Scroll 59 法莊嚴經 Fa Zhuangyan Jing (T 26, 1.0795b16) parallel to the Pali MN 89 Dhammacetiya-sutta, 2. No 168 in Scroll 43 意行經 Yi Xing Jing (T 26, 1.0700b26) parallel to the Pali MN 120 Saṅkhāruppatti-sutta, 3. No. 184 in Scroll 48 牛角娑羅林經 Niujiao Suoluolin Jing (T 26, 1.0726c27) parallel to the Pali MN 31 Cūḷagosiṅga-sutta, 4. 侍侭經 Shi Jin Jing, which lacks a Pali parallel. The Bajaur Collection includes a Gāndhārī version of a sūtra parallel to the Pāli Dakkhiṇāvibhaṅgasutta, Majjhima Nikāya No. 142, also parallel to 瞿曇彌經 No. 180, T 26 Madhyamāgama in the Chinese cannon (Strauch 2008, 19).

title: Mahābhārata
description: The Mahābhārata  is a Sanskrit epic poem, the story of the Kuru clan with the central location of the palace at Hastinapur in present-day Uttar Pradesh. It is the longest epic poem in the world. Fragments included in the Spitzer Manuscript, discovered in Qizil, date to about 130 CE.

title: Mahāmeghasūtra
description: Later Nepalese manuscript

title: Mahāparinirvāṇasūtra
description: Fragments in the Stein and Hoernle collections. This version of the Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra is contained within the Āgamas.

title: Mahāsaṃnipāta
description: Sanskrit Fragments

title: Mahāsaṅghikavinaya
description: Dutt (Gilgit) vol. III (1942)

title: Mahāvaipulya-buddha-avataṃsaka-sūtra-acintya-visaya-pradesa
description: Khotanese fragments

title: Mahāvastu
description: A collection of Jātaka and Avadāna tales and other Buddhist texts. Later Nepalese manuscript.

title: Mathurā Inscriptions
description: Inscriptions from the Kushan and Gupta empires in north-central India, including Buddhist inscriptions.

title: Maitreyavyākaraṇa
sources: Gilgit Manuscripts in the National Archives of India
description: Manuscript discovered at Gilgit.

title: Nāgārjunakoṇḍa Inscriptions
description: Inscriptions relating to Buddhist monasteries

title: Nandāvadāna
description: The story of a merchant

title: Niya Inscriptions
description: Inscriptions from the Niya site, Xinjiang

title: Prātimokṣasūtra
description: The partial manuscript cannot be reliably identified with a specific school but might have been connected to the Dharmaguptakaor or Kāśyapīya schools. The manuscript probably originated in Xinjiang. The manuscript fragments were collected in the 1910s by the Russian consular secretary P.I. Lavrov. There is also a manuscript fragment in the Bajaur Collection (Strauch 2008, 26).

title: Rastrapalapariprccha-sutra
description: Later Nepalease manuscript

title: Ratnaguṇasañcaya
description: Later Nepalease manuscript

title: Ratnaketuparivarta
description: Fragments in the Hoernle collection

title: Rhinoceros Sūtra
description: A Gāndhārī version of this sūtra recovered from birch bark fragments discovered in1994 discovery at Hadda, Afganistan also known by Pali versions in the Theravada tradition and in a Buddhist Hybdrid Sanskrit in the Mahāvastu. The content of the sūtra praises the virtues of solitude and is associated with the concept of  pratyeka-buddhas, or solitary enlightened ones.

title: Saṃdhi­nirmocana ­Sūtra
sources: National Archives of Kathmandu, German Turfan collection

title: Saṃghāṭa Sūtra
sources: Hirayama Collection and Miho Museum Collection (Matsuda, 2013)

title: Saṃgīti Sūtra
description: 1994 discovery at Hadda, Afganistan

title: Saṃyuktāgama
description: Kharosthi manuscripts

title: Saptaśatikā prajñāpāramitā
description: The Perfection of Wisdom in Seven Hundred Lines

title: Śārdūlakarṇāvadāna
description: Manuscript fragments discovered in Central Asia, written in North Brāhmī script, dating to approximately the 4th century

title: Śāriputraprakaraṇa
description: A play on the life of Śāriputra by Āśvaghōṣa. A Sanskrit manuscript was discovered in German expeditions to Xinjiang in the early 20th century.

title: Sarvapuṇyasamuccayasamādhi-sūtra
description: An early Mahayana text, Gāndhārī  fragments correspond to Jiyiqie fude sanmei jing 集一切福徳三昧經, T 12, no. 382.

title: Sarvāstivādavinaya
description: Several fragments of the Sarvāstivādavinaya have been discovered, including a fragment of the Sanskrit manuscript of the Kaṭhinavastu of the Sarvāstivādavinaya was discovered in Baicheng, Xinjiang dating to approximately the seventh or eighth century.

title: Śrāmaṇyaphala Sūtra
description: Likely to have come from the Hadda area

title: Suvarṇabhāsottamasūtra or Suvarṇaprabhāsa(uttamarāja)sūtra.
description: Manuscript fragments from the Hoernle Collection. Complete text in a later Nepalese manuscript in the Cambridge Digital Library.

title: Udānavarga
description: A text closely related to the Dharmapada. Fragments of Sanskrit manuscripts were found on the Northern Silk Road in the Northern Tarim Basin, Xinjiang.

title: Ugradattaparipṛcchā
description: Sanskrit manuscript discovered in German expeditions to Xinjiang in the early 20th century.

title: Vinaya
description: A collection of monastic rules. Gāndhārī fragments from Vinaya texts, including the Prātimokṣasūtra, have been discovered.
